Posts.Content: Hello Fifelass I have not been on here for a while, but I was informed of your post - just also wanted to say hello to Dreamthief (George) :) I was diagnosed with oestrogen receptor breast cancer, HER2 negative (fortunately) back in April 2014.  My tumour was 48mm, so quite large, in my left breast.  The surgeon offered me two options, a mastectomy or letrozole to block all oestrogen (99%) from my body and shrink the tumour.  He told me if I took this option it could take up to 18 months to shrink to 2cms which would allow them to perform a lumpectomy.  I chose this option. The surgeon also told me that each option was medically the same as the other one in relation to treating the tumour.  I was on letrozole for 15 months with regular examinations at the breast clinic to check the tumour was softening and decreasing in size, which it did. The side effects of letrozole were not easy for me, but they did their  job of shrinking the tumour for less invasive surgery.  I really did not want a mastectomy, as I do not have small boobs, not big, but I would still have been lopsided afterwards and I was not willing to have a mastectomy if I could retain some of my breast.  As the surgeon said there was no difference between either option, I chose to have the letrozole to shrink the tumour first.. I had a four hour surgery at the beginning of last August 2015 with a partial  LD Flap reconstruction.  It was a bigger surgery than I thought it would be as unfortunately during the biopsy they had inadvertently seeded another cancer from the tumour biopsy on the skin of my breast.  Therefore this had to be cut out too to ensure this had not gone below the surface.  Because I was on the letrozole, the drug had prevented this occurring.  They also managed to leave my nipple so my breast is starting to heal and recover from the surgery and radiation and certainly looks much better than it did.  I completely understand how you feel about going for a long time with a tumour in your body.  Fortunately I did not feel this way, as each time I was examined the tumour was shrinking and softening and NOT growing or spreading.  It maybe that you may feel this way yourself as time goes on and your tumour starts to soften and shrink, which it is as you have said, and  they have told you it is softening which means it will decrease in size with time. My surgeon told me that oestrogen inhibitor drugs can take some time, but they do the job and also help systemically, meaning if a breast cancer cell moved to a different part of the body, the letrozole would stop it growing.  It is a very good drug and they probably  will want you to be on this for five years afterwards anyway. I understand that a year can seem like an eternity to be on the drug before surgery, but it will be worth it in the end when they will be able to do a lumpectomy rather than a mastectomy. My tumour shrank from 4.8cms to 2.2 cms, so more than half in fifteen months.  It was a long haul, I know, but you can do this and I would be very happy to be in touch with you, if you do make the decision to stay on letrozole,  to help in any way I can. Also, it may not be a year - it totally depends on how fast the tumour softens and shrinks ready for surgery. I hope I have helped in some way. With my thoughts to you and I am very happy to keep in touch. Heather

Posts.Content: Hello Carol I empathise with you regarding letrozole side effects, as I had a bad time with them too.  Many women struggle as AI inhibitors stop all oestrogen production and so we are almost without any oestrogen at all in our bodies, so of course this can affect our joints and muscles and has many other side effects!  Some fare better than others with this drug.  I was determined to stay on letrozole until I was able to have surgery.  I decided not to take it for the 5-10 year stint after surgery and radiation because of the SEs I experienced and my oncologist agreed with me With regard to the specific brand of letrozole making a difference, I can't say it did for me  to any extent although many on this board seem to have less SEs with different brands.  I used Sandoz mainly, which seemed to be  slightly better than the others.  It can depend on the fillers they use too as to whether the SEs can be more difficult.  IMO, it is a question of trying different brands and using the one that appears to be easier for you. I, too, have an underactive thyroid and I agree, it can be an inexact science getting the dose right as it can go up and down.  Personally,  I need my TSH level to be 1 or under, otherwise I have a problem.  There is certainly evidence to suggest that if you have a TSH level over 2, you will have problems, although the range for diagnosing an underactive thyroid is 0.33-4.  My body certainly needs to be below 2 and preferably below 1 for me to feel reasonable. As for statins, they wanted me on them several years ago and I refused.  This seems to have become a very controversial drug and the drug companies have been utterly disingenuous about the side effects. I am sorry to hear you have been getting extremely dry eyes and double vision.  I wonder if the double vision could be related to your extremely dry eyes.  I, too have dry eyes, more particularly during the night so use hypomellose drops.  I have had blephartitis for many years so this creates dry eyes.  I did find my eyes a little worse whilst on letrozole though.  It will be good for you to find out what is going on when you have your appointment at the hospital. Carol, please do not think you are complaining, you have breast cancer and and this is a serious diagnosis!   It is perfectly normal that you would feel like this.  Someone told me at the beginning of the cancer road back in 2014 that being diagnosed with breast cancer (or any cancer) was like being in a foreign land and having  to learn a foreign language.  This analogy was, for me, exactly how I felt.  This forum helped me enormously for over one and half years.  The people are terrific with so muchknowledge  time and empathy to help you through the road you are now travelling.  Believe me, you CAN do this, it will not be easy, but you will develop the inner strength and resilience that will hold you together with your treatment, - honestly.!  My experience of cancer and its treatment changed me hugely and in a positive way.  I realised, as have so many of us, just what was really important in my life and in life itself.   Please stay in touch and complain as much as you want. Wtih my thoughts to you. Heather x

Posts.Content: Hello Judith I am in my 10th month of letrozole neo-adjuvant, as I believe you may remember.  I am so sorry you have so many SEs with Anastrozole.  I empathise with you  as I have SEs with letrozole particularly joint painin my legs, knees and feet.  Also hot flashes although much less than at the start.  Sleeping is a problem too with a few night sweats etc .  All of these SEs are, as we all know, because of the blocking of all oestrogen by the AI  drugs. Posts.Title: Feeling so angry tired and weak

Posts.Content: Hello Helen I have been on letrozole for six months prior to surgery in order to shrink the tumour.  It was 48mm and is now 26mm x 27mm, at the beginning of September, so   has shrunk 40% in just four months.  I understand completely about aching joints, insomnia and mood swings.  My joints are very painful particularly at night when I am in bed.  To try to keep them moving so it does not disrupt life too much I walk about 2-3 miles per day.  It does make a difference as they are less stiff.  I also take vitamin D, calcium and B complex.  I also eat a lot of fresh fruit, salads and vegetables and very little red meat, just chicken and fish.  I do eat chocolate sometimes as I do not drink or smoke so figure I want to do something nice for me  - Well that's my excuse anyway LOLOL Initially was also getting over 20 hot flushes per day.  These are much less now and down to less than half that number.  My oncologist said that he would change the pills, but there was not a lot of choice.  I decided to stay with letrozole, the devil I know!   The problem is that these Aromatase inhibitors all have the same core action of blocking oestrogen from our bodies, which results in various similar  side effects.  I was reading an article today in the Mail about women who go through the menopause and have very similar side effects and how difficult it is for them.  The problem for us ladies with these AIs, is that we have very little, if any,  oestrogen in our bodies, so the side effects are much worse.  After menopause when the ovaries stop producing oestrogen, we still have some oestrogen in our bodies and  HRT is an option depending on our GP.  I took a very low dose of HRTpatches  for many years so did not go through the menopause.  When I started on the letrozole and came off HRT of course as my BC is ER positive (8x8).  You know how women dream of wonderful looking guys, like Jose Mourinho - well I dream about oestrogen - honestly:) I live on my own too, Helen, although I am retired, but do voluntary work pretty full time.  I do understand that sense of being on your own with all of this and not feeling supported.  I have the surgery ahead at some point in the next few months.  The breast care nurses have never returned three calls over the last six months so I gave up.  I then called MacMillan support linerecently  and had a very nice volunteer on the phone who said she would have a BC nurse call me. That was two weeks ago and no call.  I give up and just read the posts on here for support or information. I am so sorry that you feel you have not had the care you need and that you did not have a mammogram for your yearly check,which would give you more comfort when you are so anxious and also the fact you were told you could have reconstruction and now you cannot.  Did he say why this was? With my thoughts Heather x

Posts.Title: Letrozole side effects

Posts.Content: Hello Everyone I am four weeks post radiation.  Unfortunately I did not have a very good time with it.  Many side effects and had burn by the 4th treatment.  I also ended up in A & E, but all is much better now.   I saw my oncologist yesterday for my four week check and he did say that I was in the worst group for radiation side effects and said I still looked very red, but actually  I found it has been a little better in the last few days.  He said it would heal gradually but may not ever get back to how it was before.  Well with the reconstruction partial LD flap, it looks a little odd anyway, so I am not particularly concerned about this LOL. We discussed me going back to the letrozole or other hormone inhibitor, but I had written down many of the side effects I had taking this for  15 months prior to my surgery and that I felt I could not go back on them again.  He agreed that the side effects I experienced would result in awful quality of life against only a small percentage in preventing recurrence risk,  3%. and felt that it would be better for my life quality not to take these anymore.  He also felt that even a different AI would not make much difference to me.  Anyway with his support, I feel as though I have made the right decision for me..   So this is it, the end of my treatment - just have to go back to see my surgeon for my six monthly check next February.  I feel very, very glad it is all over after 20 months and I want to move forward now and live life again, once the tiredness and radiation effects have diminished. I am so very grateful for this site and for those  ladies and guys who have supported me and helped me through this cancer diagnosis and treatment from beginning to end.  You have my  huge appreciation and my thoughts for all of your comfort, kindness, wisdom and understanding.  I could not have done it without you all pushing me forward. For all those beginning this  journey, know that you can do it, one day at a time.  Try not to look ahead too far, remain in the present if you can, and each day your treatment will be gathering pace reaching out towards the end of treatment and then healing and recovery.  You think it will never come, the end of this cancer road, but it can and it does.  I have seen such courage here.  It has moved me so much and taught me even more about the human spirit and the will to survive this dreadful disease and its treatment.  I know this - I will never be the same person again as I  realise now just how fragile and precious life is and that those people you love become even more precious to you.  It has also given me great glimpses of the endurance and courage of the human spirit and I have also seen humanity at its  very best. I would particularly like to thank George for all his humour and his wisdom, Helen, Julia and everyone who took the time to respond to my posts.  Thank you each and everyone of you. With my warm personal regards to you all and may Christmas bring something beautiful and much comfort for each of you. Heather

Posts.Title: Where do I go from here, part two

Posts.Content: Hello Jantr I was diagnosed April 2014 with 4.8cm tumour in my left breast and chose to go on letrozole to shrink the tumour in order to have WLE.  Fifteen months later I had my surgery on August 3rd this year.  I also had to have a partial LD flap as I had about a third of my breast taken. My experiences on letrozole were pretty awful, extreme joint pain knees, hips, feet, neck, tiredness, 8-10 hot flushes per day, constipation, stomach problems and generally feeling as though I was not 'me' anymore.  I had to keep going to take the letrozole as it was doing its job and shrinking the tumour.  Pathology results showed tumour at 2.2 cms so the tumour size had reduced by 2.6cms and no cancer in the three lymph nodes they took.  After surgery and during my five days in the hospital I asked my surgeon if I could have a break from the letrozole.  He said I could have a two week break and when I asked for longer, he said that would be okay, but I must discuss it with my oncologist when I started my radiotherapy, which starts this Saturday for three weeks.   I told my oncologist I could not face going back on the letrozole  while I was going through RT and the side effects.  He said this was ok and that we would discuss this when my treatment has finished.  I think it is highly unlikely I will go back on any of these Aromatase inhibitors as they impacted my life so much and, for me, I want quality of life not longevity. However,  after my surgery and when I went back for a check at the clinic two weeks after my operation, one of the surgeons on my surgical team told me that it was important that I did take letrozole or one of the other  AI drugs, as systemically and locally, it would be a safety valve to try to prevent recurrence. She told me that taking it and having some breaks from it was better than not taking it at all!  So...something to think about.  I have been off letrozole for nearly ten weeks now, since my surgery and there is a huge difference in how I feel, joints are much better, particularly my neck which was really dire while I was on letrozole.  I don't get that extreme tiredness I used to get and I have a  only a couple of hot flushes per day, but nowhere near the intensity they used to be and nightsweats have all but gone too.  I understand how difficult this decision will be and of course it does make sense that they want us to take AI inhibitors when we have had  oestrogen receptor cancer - but there is always a price to pay for cancer treatments  and I think it is a very personal decision  as to what we want to do. My oncologist also said to me that if the side effects of letrozole outweigh the risks of recurrence , then it is a big decision to have to make. I wish you well and I am so sorry that you got shingles on top of everything else especially on holiday. Take good care With a hug Heather

Posts.Content: Hello Valerie-anne I have been on letrozole for 9months now to shrink the tumour prior to surgery this year.  I am in my sixties. I empathise with you on your energy levels and low mood as I have these too in addition to hot flashes (not as many as the beginning) and joint pain.  I have not gained weight, not that I ever weigh myself, but clothes are fine.  I think this is because I don't feel very hungry most of the time and eat less than I did before I was on letrozole.  However, I do walk just about every day about 2miles to keep my joints moving as they feel so stiff  and uncomforable in the mornings and when rising from sitting or being in bed.  I think the walking helps to balance effects of weight gain  and I eat a lot of fruit and vegetables, very little red, meat, just chicken, salmon, tuna and sardines. I used to eat like this before cancer diagnosis so nothing much has changed, except I eat less.   I do like rice and bread, but not much for pasta or potatoes I don't drink or smoke, but I do like chocolate sometimes:). Blocking oestrogen from our bodies on these hormone inhibitor drugs will have quite a few  side effects. I would highly recommend walking, if you feel up to it, maybe  just around the block and gradually increase each day.  I started at ten minutes and now do about 40 minutes depending how I feel.   Are you taking letrozole after having had your treatment?   With my thoughts Heather

Posts.Title: Living with Letrozole, as wel as breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hello Yellowroses Back in April 2014, I was diagnosed with a largish tumour of 4.8 cms.  I took letrozole for 15 months and it shrank in size to 2.2 cms  so by more than half.  I did have to have a partial mastectomy then and reconstruction surgery, but all is well over two years on. As you describe your breast tumour as smallish and already decreasing in size, this is great news.  As it shrinks, it also becomes softer, which is good.  Letrozole can take time to reduce size, but it ensures that oestrogen levels are dramatically reduced thus taking away the oestrogen that oestrogen receptor cancer needs in order to grow.   Letrozole works well and if you also keep fit, this will help your joints.  I walked two to three miles a day whilst on letrozole to keep my joints reasonable With thoughts to you Heather
Posts.Title: Living with Letrozole, as wel as breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hello Lilley I am in my 60s and have BC.  I have been on letrozole (very similar to Anastrazole) for over five months to shrink the tumour before surgery.  I have gained very llittle weight.  I walk every day for about 45 minutes doing about two miles or so.  For me I have found this really helps with regard to controlling weight and also helps the bone and muscle pain.  I also take a multiple vitamin and mineral supplement in addition to vitamin D3 and I eat a lot of fruit and vegetables, which I always did anyway..  I do not get as many hot flushes and night sweats as I did, but my memory is a little foggy at times without oestroen and I used to have an excellent memory so I do think this is related to the letrozole. Wishing you the very best in making the right decision. Good wishes Heather
Posts.Title: Not sure what to do can anyone help

Posts.Content: Hello jmp Thank you so very much for taking the time to write such a lengthy and informative response .  It is soooo appreciated:)  I am using replens although can't get this via my GP as they only have the capacity to precribe the other one, which is useless!  I do have the email address of my breast care nurse, but they just seem so busy.  However I will email her instead with my questions.  I am sorry to hear you have lymphoedema in your breast.  It is seems to be very common after this surgery.  I hope you are okay? Do you mean don't do any heavy lifting on op side before surgery or after?  I did have a bonedensity scan last week as my oncologist requested this when I started on the letrozole although it took a long time for an appointment.  I do not know the results yet.  I am sorry to hear that your bone density results are edging toward osteoporosis and I know this is a very common side effect. I exercise by  walking every day for about half an hour and also eat a lot of fruit, salads and vegetables,but I always have.  I am sorry about your hair loss - is a little or a lot or just thinning?  I haven't noticed anything yet, but have only been on the drug for 9 weeks.  I am sosorry you have been on your own through all of this and that you had moved to a new location.  That must have been very challenging for you when you most need your friends and family around - well depending on the relationship you have with them!   I have a guy friend who has been around and very caring, but unfortunately this means he is here at my home more, which I appreciate, but it is not ideal for many personal reasons.  i have one son of 27 and he lives and work in London.  He has been very supportive, but, again he is not here and works crazy hours.  Otherwise I have no social network up here in the Northeast.  Friends are in the London and Yorkshire area.  I have been to a place called 'Maggie's' which is wonderful.  It is a cancer centre and I believe there are 17 around the UK. I do try to look at this in a more positive way,but I am not succeeding really.  I am a very strong woman but somehow this diagnosis has prevented me processing this differently.  I have been offered antidepressants by my doctor, but I do not want them.  In fact I feel as though I do not want anything else that is toxic to my body.  The cancer and letrozole are enough together with several other pills I take for blood pressure and hypothyroidism. I so appreciate your thoughtful response ...thank you so much. Best wishes Heather
Posts.Title: Confused with lack of support and not enough information

Posts.Content: Hello Misty Thank you for your interesting thoughts here.  I have had high blood pressure since my early fifties and I am on three different pills, so not the drug creating this, although it maybe that this will prevent the BP pills I am on keeping it normal as much, as one of the side effectsof these drugs  is high blood pressure. I am sorry to see you now have high BP of very recent time.  This could well be because of tamoxifen.  Funny this because I was on HRT for many, many years, very low dose patch  and I felt good on it even though breast cancer could be a slight possibility, I was willing to take the chance.    Oncologist said that HRT may have been a factor, but it may not have been as other women of my age who have never taken HRT have this ER breast cancer. I have been hypothyroid for several years and on 125 mcgs per day although this can go up and down as it is a very inexact science as I am sure you know:) I am not sure I could continue with letrozole or something similar after surgey and radiation.  I feel like you, quality of life over longevity of life:) With regard to TSH levels only,  I know exactly what you mean, but sadly that is exactly what they do, or more accurately what the labs do.  If you are within range then all is well - NOT.  The whole hypothyroid debate is a complex one  and it seems that some GPs do not look at the whole picture  of physical effects and how the patient feels - and sadly, neither do some of the endrocrinologists. Funny old world.... Take care Heather
Posts.Title: Confused with lack of support and not enough information

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with grade 2 breast cancer in April, 4cms. It is oestrogen receptive so I am on letrozole for past two months plus. Hot flashes at least 15 plus per day, night sweats, bad joint pain in legs feet and knees. Still have some nausea and very tired and in a low mood sometimes. Oncologist appointment last week. Oncologist pleased with result as tumour softening and possibly slightly smaller. He was a different oncologist from the one I had been seeing and was rather brusque and obviously in a hurry so not conducive to any questions but told me that those not on letrozole would be feeling hot as the weather had been humid! I decided not challenge this remark as he made it apparent he had limited time.. I go back again in September to see if the tumour has decreased any more so we can discuss lumpectomy surgery. Then there will be radiation and then on hormone meds for 5 years. I have called my BCN several times leaving a message and have not had a response on two occasions, then I called Macmillan support to talk with someone and after 15 minutes of waiting with the same message playing over and over, I gave up. This support board has given me a lot of information, somewhat frightening at times but the courage shown by so many women and men is breathtaking and humbling. Outside of this Board, I have felt somewhat unsupported by my oncology team. I know how busy they are but This cancer diagnosis changes your life as you know and it is like living in another world reality and learning a different language. Help please... Best wishes Heather
Posts.Title: Confused with lack of support and not enough information

Posts.Content: Thank you, Helen.  I appreciate your response and you are right Oncologists and cancer teams have to be detached from all the emotive issues and of course only those have travelled this route can truly understand. Without a doubt, removing just about all all oestrogen from your body via these drugs causes all kinds of effects.  It is not just like going through menopause but much more than that because there is no oestrogen at all. I think if I was younger, I may have a somewhat different perspective, but frankly at 68 and with this gruelling time ahead and years on this drug to limit cancer returning is not how I wanted to live the few latter years of my life.  I have been a very busy person in retirement having two voluntary roles which are pretty full time.  Now I do not have the energy for much and the joint pain is a real problem.  I think if I was taking letrozole, having surgery down the line and then radiation and then could stop taking letrozole, I may feel differently. Thank you for your thoughts:) Heather

Posts.Content: Hello Chloecat So sorry to hear you had a minor stroke and that it affected your  right eye, although very  happy   to hear all was well in the neck arteries and brain.  In 2008, I had a macro aneurysm in my right eye, which I know is not the same, but it was like a laser light show going on in my eye and a little frightening. The major contributory factor was high blood pressure over a period of time.  I was already on two blood pressure pills anyway.  However, i was very lucky and only have a small area at the bottom of the right eye that has a little grey area.  The bleeding in the eye resolved over a period of ten months as the blood was absorbed back into my blood stream.  Apparently it just missed my central vision so I was very lucky.  In fact my reading is better in my right eye than my left eye...ironic!  There was a lot of bleeding because at the  time I took low dose aspirin, which created a bigger bleed.  I do not take it any more. They added another BP pill making three, but it keeps my blood pressure very low!  You are absolutely right about about BP.  It is so important to get BP checked regularly or get a cuff and check it yourself, preferable when resting with your feet up so it is a realiable indicate of if blood pressure is healthy at rest. As for me, I am fine, two years past my operation and partial reconstruction back in August 2015.  Had a scare three weeks ago as had a problem with it, swollen, red etc.  They were very quick and had mammogram US and they expedited the results for the following day, it was an infection.  Antibiotics cleared it up.  I have lymphodema in the reconstructed boob from the radiation, but manage this with massage.. My cholesterol is 6.7, but due to the never ending controversy about statins, I do not take them.  I am in Helen's court over this one, but I think it is up to every individual as to what they feel is better for their health. Take good care of  yourself and I wish you a full recovery in your eye. With many best wishes Heather

Posts.Content: Hello Julia :) How are you?  I have been following this thread, as although I do not receive forum emails now into my inbox, this thread has arrived in my email. I agree with all your thoughts here.  It is a very individual choice to make an informed decision about treatment, whether conventional or otherwise as long as we have looked at all the clinical information on both sides of the cancer coin, so to speak. As for me, I am happy that  I made the right choice for me with conventional treatment of neo adjuvant letrozole for 15 months prior to my surgery and  LD flap  reconstruction, then radiotherapy.  I had horrible side effects with the letrozole but it did the job of shrinking the tumour from 4.8 cms to 2.2cms,  I was also lucky in having a very skilled surgeon, and ten and half months on the scars on my breast and back are healing well, although I do have lymphoedema in my boob.  This is, of course, because of the radiation, but funnily enough the skin on the actual LD flap, is just fine, it is the rest of the skin on the  boob that has been a problem because of the radiation. I am awaiting an appointment at the Lymphoedema clinic now Had a mammogram last week, so awaiting the results which could take up to four weeks.  I am not taking the adjuvant letrozole for five years as both myself and oncologist felt that the side effects I had against the percentage of recurrence would  affect my quality of life.  But hey-ho, I am seventy and I am grateful for extra time, so whatever will be WILL be. I am enjoying my life now, albeit a little slower with less energy at times, but I am grateful to be alive and have had good support from the NHS and my surgical team here in Newcastle upon Tyne. I would like to pass on my thoughts and warmest wishes to those on the board who are undergoing cancer treatment..  I am  different in many ways from before my diagnosis, as we all are, but I believe these changes have been profound and positive for me. Take care dear Julia Heather xx

Posts.Content: Hello Helen, Lavender girl and everyone on this thread I am not on this forum very often now, but I was for twenty months whilst going through treatment.  This thread has come through to my inbox and I thought I would give my thoughts and experience as people on this forum supported and comforted me during those long months.   I learned so much from so many extraordinary women and men going through a breast cancer diagnosis.  I am over two years in remission and cancer free in the present time.  I was on letrozole for 15 months prior to     Surgery where I also had reconstruction.  My tumour was rather big, 48mm, hence the long time on letrozole in order to avoid a mastectomy.  I ended up with a partial mastectomy and LD flap reconstruction at the same time so was a four hour surgery.  This was followed by three weeks radiation six weeks later. Unfortunately I had a bad time with the radiation, but I got through it and I was lucky I did not need chemotherapy.  My tumour was Oestrogen receptor cancer (8x8).  They took three lymph nodes and there was no cancer there, so I consider myself to be very fortunate. I had a bad time with the letrozole during the 15 months, but it is all a very individual experience as some ladies only experience minimal effects.  I was familiar with Chloecat's thread, and at one stage considered alternative options myself as her threads are informed and honest about her experiences in the alternative routes.  However I made the decision to go with the medical science route and I did this because I was able to discuss  my thoughts and feelings with others on this forum and make what I considered to be an informed choice.  I also chose not to take letrozole for five years after treatment because of the side effects.  This was discussed and agreed with my oncologist.  As we all go forward with the courage strength and resilience that it takes with a diagnosis like this, we can support each other with all our different views and feelings because in the end we have each other to draw on and share our fears, our laughter and our tears and we can become stronger because of it. My thoughts are with you all as you take this road and when I was first diagnosed back in April of 2017, someone said to me...cancer diagnosis is like being in a foreign land where you have to learn a foreign language rather quickly.  How right she was, but in my experience it also  gives you a strength you never knew you had and you are different at the other end , but in a way that is profoundly positive...funnily enough... With my love and a hug to each of you Heather

Posts.Content: Hello Pat I am Heather77 who Dreamthief refers to:) I was diagnosed with Invasive ductal carcinoma in April of last year. It was oestrogen receptor positive (8x8) so the fully monty, so to speak:)  My tumour size was quite big - 4.8cms.  According to the ultrasound, there was no evidence of lymph node involvement.   My surgeon gave me two options, which were a mastectomy or an Aromatase Inhibitor, letrozole, which could  take  up to eighteen months to shrink the tumour to below 2cms for lumpectomy surgery.  As Dreamthief said, I was on letrozole for fifteen months and I had surgery in the form of a quadrantectomy, removing the tumour, (2.2 cms) three sentinel lymph nodes and a partial LD flap reconstruction.  At diagnosis the surgeon said each option was clinically the same. Letrozole is very similiar to anastrozole and is another AI hormone inhibitor.  The surgeon was very happy with the results as they checked me throughout  the fifteen months - the tumour softened  hugely and kept shrinking slowly, but surely, so in fact by the time I had surgery on 3rd August, two and half weeks ago, it had decreased in size by 2.6cms. Not only was it not growing, but it was shrinking!  The action of letrozole and all four hormone inhibitors  blocked the oestrogen from allowing the tumour to grow.  There are indeed side effects and they can be very challenging, BUT it absolutely did its job. My tumour pathology results on Tuesday were such wonderful news.  The surgical team got all the margins!!  There were NO cancer cells in the three lymph nodes they took.  I have to heal and recover for a further four weeks as it was a significant surgery and then will be having three weeks of radiotherapy at the Freeman Hospital here in Newcastle.  This is a safety valve to give more of a chance of  stopping any random cancer cells still in my breast. The surgical nurse who saw me on Tuesday in addition encouraged me to stay on letrozole or one of the hormone inhibitor drugs as apparently it decreases the chances of the cancer returning or spreading by 25%.  I have had two and half weeks break from letrozole and a further two weeks prior to seeing the oncologist before having radiotherapy.  The nurse suggested that even taking letrozole and having two week breaks on occasion was far better than not taking it at all.  They want me to discuss this with the oncologist prior to RT. So, Pat, it has certainly been my experience that hormone inhibitors such as Anastrozole, letrozole, Arimidex and Exestamane are VERY effective and absolutely necessary.  The SEs can be awful, but seem to vary from person to person.  The main experiences I had were extreme joint pain, hot flashes, night sweats, extreme tiredness and lack of energy.  I gritted my teeth and kept on going and I am very happy with my pathology results and my surgical team and the wonderful nurses who took care of me during my stay in hospital - and, as I expressed in a recent post, the caring and huge support I received on this extraordinary Macmillan Forum. Sorry for the length of this, but hope this helps:) Heather

Posts.Content: Hi Jan Yes,  feeling this way and very tired is perfectly normal after only six weeks!   You had MAJOR surgery and you will not feel too good for quite a while.  Your body has been through a lot with an LD flap reconstruction, so it is rather battered and needs to reserve energy in order to heal and recover.  You need plenty of sleep which is when your body uses reserves to heal. My surgeon told me it would take two months or more before I could drive and that I should just potter for a couple of months or more.  I am retired, but I do work from home in a voluntary capacity which can be very busy at times.  I did not feel like doing much for quite a while and felt very tired and in pain sometimes too. With regard to your customers, are they thinking of you in pestering you to go back?  Of course not.  IMHO, I think it may be wise to tell them that you have had cancer and major reconstruction surgery and you are not ready to go back yet.  It would not be conducive to go back to hairdressing after only six weeks recovery,  as this is a very active job with regard to using the side where you have had surgery  -  and the movement would be difficult for you and hinder your healing. The exercises are very important - I still do mine one year after surgery.  Have you had any physiotherapy with some massage on the scar on your back to help the skin?   Jan, my advice to you is to try and relax, not to worry about how long  your recovery is taking.  Everyone is different, but remember your body has undergone  a lot of trauma with an operation like this.  It needs time - lots of it - to gradually recover.  Relax and allow your precious body to do this:) Take good care of YOU - your customers will have to wait! with every good wish and my thoughts to you. Heather X

Posts.Content: Hello jwoowoo I had a partial mastectomy and an LD flap reconstruction August last year.  Five weeks is a hugely short time for your healing and recovery.  This is a major operation.  The surgery involves taking your back main muscle, and tunnelling this muscle, breast tissue and blood vessels under your arm into your breast.  Your body has undergone a traumatic operation and it takes much time to heal.  I expected miracles too and realised that my body needed time, care and rest as I gradually recovered more movement and energy.  I was on pain killers for a couple of months after the operation.    It takes quite a lot of time to feel normal again and everyone is different in their healing and recovery.  Take it easy on yourself and take one day at a time.  Try not to have definitive expectations of how soon you should be fully recovered.  Getting your strength back will happen very gradually physically, emotionally and psychologically.   For me it took around six months to feel normal again and to regain all the movement, energy and strength.  The breast care reconstruction nurses told me it can take up to a year for full recovery. Eventually all will be well again..... With my thoughts and a hug Heather

Posts.Content: Hello again Gill Yes, if you have small breasts a 14mm tumour would feel rather large and scary.  Mine certainly felt large at 48mm and I do not have small breasts, more medium plus size.  I was also diagnosed with grade 2 ductal carcinoma ER positive 8/8, HER negative. Don't know the Ki67 8%, will check this out. As far as I am aware, and I am  not a medical person, letrozole can stop the tumour from growing and then start to shrink it as oestrogen levels become extremely limited.    My surgeon originally told me I could be on letrozole for around 18 months as it depends how soon it starts to work to decrease the size.  I would suggest that they would be more concerned if your tumour was increasing rather than not decreasing in size at the moment .  With the two weeks pf tamoxifen you were taking this means you have been taking  letrozole for ten weeks, so I am sure it will have stopped it growing and maybe just taking some time to start to decrease the size of your tumour. I totally understand about the side effects of letrozole.  I had all the side  effects you mention plus several more.  The hot flushes  were dreadful.  I was getting around 20-25 per day - previously I had been on HRT for many years, so I think going from having a supply of oestrogen to hardly any at all, gave me extreme  effects.  After around six months the hot flushes settled down to 8-12 per day.  I still hated them though, but I was determined to persevere. I, too, had awful problems with my joints.  I am afraid this lack of oestrogen affects many parts of the body, more so than the natural menopause.  I used to  walk two to three miles every day to keep my joints moving and this did help.  I would also suggest  that you moisturise your skin very well as it can become dry and drink plenty of water, fresh fruit and vegetable etc. You will probably notice that you feel more tired, but walking or some form of exercise helps to keep the oxygen circulating:) I bought those little battery operated fans which I always carried in my handbag for when I had my inevitable daily hot flushes. I also found laughter was the greatest healer of all and I laughed a lot and posted on this forum for help when I felt low.  The support, wisdom and courage of all the people here, past and present, gave me the strength to keep on going. When I was first diagnosed with breast cancer someone said something very profound to me - it was this - 'being diagnosed with cancer is like all of a sudden being in a foreign land and you have to learn a foreign  language'  .  She was absolutely right and although a cancer diagnosis is hugely  frightening and you are walking in uncharted waters,  you WILL find your way through and find the resilience, hope and support to keep on going. I am not the same person that I was, but cancer taught me so much about myself, my resilience and also about what it really means to be human.  More importantly it taught me so much about those extraordinary people who have walked this path and their advice, hope and courage shines through absolutely everything. Gill, please feel free to ask anything you want and if I can help in some small way I would be very happy to do so. With my thoughts to you. Heather x

Posts.Content: Hello Gill Thank you for the correction to the size of your tumour.  When is your appointment with your surgeon regarding what they want to do ?  Ask him/her lots of questions and I would advise you to write these down prior to going so you can be as informed as possible and make your decisions based on this.  Do you have family to go with you? Yes, I cried all the time.  It could be anything, the cancer adverts on television, a sad movie or song, something someone says when they are talking with you and trying to help - or just your own thoughts as you try to process everything that is happening and what may or may not happen in the future.  May I suggest, if possible, that you try to take only one day at a time.  As wise lady on this forum, a while back ,said if you keep looking into the future with great anxiety then  you will  lose the gift of  today. I still cry more than I used to ten months after finishing treatment.  I think there are several reasons for this - the fact that I survived 20 rather gruelling months and that I found a resilience in me that I had no idea was there.  My mammogram in June was good in that they said 'no cause for concern'.  I have a wonderful surgeon, skilled, funny and with a warmth that he radiates - on top of that he is good looking:) LOL My experience of this difficult road  has taught me so much, so, yes, I still cry more when I recall many things and when I recall the amazing  people on this forum.  They taught me so much and for this I am very grateful.   Always look at the positive, not the negative, always hope and always laugh - and in my experience, those I love have become the core of what is really significant in my life, even more so than before. They know so much about different breast cancers now and it is that medical science that will treat your tumour and even though the treatment can be very difficult, there will be a day when it will be all over and then they will check you with yearly mammograms and breast checks.  I am in Newcastle upon Tyne and the RVI hospital here  is excellent.  I am due there next Tuesday for another check. Take good care of you and distract with whatever you like to do.  One step at a time...l with love Heather x

Posts.Content: Hello J and Julia Thank you so much for your thoughtful responses.  It helps a lot to have advice from those who have travelled this road. I am hoping the pathology results are okay, if not, I am not sure how I will emotionally react.  I am so tired and so fed up.  I was fifteen months on letrozole before my operation trying to reduce tumour size.  It was still 3cms when they operated in addition to the further cancer nodule on my breast  seeded by the original biopsy. My surgeon also had to make two incisions in my back for the LD flap for some reason I cannot now remember. I feel very, very low, but I am trying to process this.  For the first time in my life I am not sure I will make it.  The last 13 years have been full of major trauma on and off and I think I am on the edge.  I have an onco clinic psychologist, but nothing is helping and I definitely do not want antidepressants.  For some reason my body seems to be so sensitive to all drugs, I seem to get so many side effects.  I know I have stop going down this dark road and normally I can and change direction.  I am finding it all very difficult now. The good news is that I am having a 'holiday' from letrozole.  Believe me my joints and hot flushes are 70% better.  It is amazing.  However, I am sure my surgeon will want me back on an AI soonish. Need to find the percentage rates.  I am 70 next week and want some quality in my life for whatever time I have left. Just feeling low and trying to be strong. Heather xx
